ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Memorizing large bits of information, all the bones in the human body
You learn how to identify and side bones and their parts.
I was able to grasp anatomy and its applications in osteology a lot better.
Learn to site and recognize different bones and get to know sex and age approximation

I learned how to identify the bones in the body and also how to identify different parts of those bones! Also I learned how to use various bones to age and sex individuals. Also, I learned which muscles originated and inserted at each of the different locations of the bones.
identification of human skeletal parts and distinction of age and sex group of the recognized skeletons, as well as basic introduction to the muscular-skeletal system.
Memorized every bone in the human body, including the bony features and muscles that attach to each of them.
bones and their parts
I gained the ability to memorize and identify bone features and muscle insertions. I really learned a lot about human anatomy, as well as the function of muscles and bones.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Kind instructor, well-taught, good study guide, straightforward exams, relatively quick grading and feedback.
Areas for Improvement: It was difficult to find good images and they were sometimes labelled incorrectly, the slides were not always informative in helping with studying, and the exams would be the very class after we'd just learned the concepts (this one was likely due to it being a summer class).

Strengths- Good science course to get your distributional requirement 
Weaknesses- Course was not that engaging

The fast pace is both an advantage and a flaw. Having some graded take home papers in between could be helpful. There were some online ressources available but they didn't quite take the form of the final quizzes.

Good outline of the class 
the quiz picture cannot load sometimes

The course was very informative. Every topic was covered on time. Professor Sargis even provided useful extra information. I was well informed about all the topics to be covered, the quiz dates and all the material was easily available.
Sometimes it was difficult to identify bones and their features in the pictorial form. The pictures were missing in some quizzes and we had to view them on our second device.

Strengths of the course include that the images used for labeling the bones are very clearly defined which makes it easy to learn and remember them. In my opinion there were no weaknesses in the course - it was one of the best I've ever taken at Yale.

On the third exam, there was super little time to study for (in my opinion) the hardest exam out of the four, but either way I think it was manageable. Professor Sargis just forgot to post the lecture before the day of the lecture so that's why it was really hard, I think.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if they want a straightforward and honest science credit that is not a gut.
yes
Yes, it was very informative and enabled me to learn difficult concepts with ease.

Yes - learning bone identification is so useful for many different fields and Dr. Sargis has such a vast wealth of information that you learn so much in the course about bone formation and such in addition to just simple identification.

I would not recommend this course to anyone unless they are seriously interested in the topic. I took this course expecting it to be a fairly easy science credit to take over the summer, but this could not have been further from the truth. Unless you are prepared to study for hours and hours memorizing bony features and muscle attachments of every bone in the human body for each exam, I would not recommend this course.
only if you are really good at memorization
Yes! I really enjoyed this class and I learned a lot about how college classes work.
